nodes.text: Conflict between printed color and color name produces asymmetric interference: habitual word-reading responses interfere more with naming ink-colors than color stimuli interfere with reading words; practice alters these interference effects

Materials: stimuli comprised five color names (red, blue, green, brown, purple) each printed in the four other ink-colors so that each item simultaneously presented a word stimulus and a conflicting color stimulus; duplicates printed in black and in color squares/swastikas provided comparison conditions
Experiment 1 procedure: subjects read lists of color names printed either in black (RCNb) or printed in ink of a different color (RCNd); measure = time to read 100 names
Experiment 2 procedure: subjects named ink-colors presented either as color squares (NC) or as printed color names whose ink color differed from the word (NCWd); measure = time to name 100 colors

Experiment 3 procedure: subjects practiced naming ink-colors of conflicting printed words (NCWd) across multiple days to assess practice effects on NCWd, NC, and RCNd performance and on group variability

Assumptions: reaction time differences between paired stimulus conditions index interference magnitude; prior training history explains differential habitual strength for word-reading versus color-naming
Materials detail consequence: RCNd vs RCNb measures color-stimulus interference on word reading; NCWd vs NC measures word-stimulus interference on color naming

Result Experiment 1: reading color names printed in conflicting ink-colors (RCNd) increased mean time by only 2.3 seconds (about 5.6%) compared with black print (RCNb); this small increase was not statistically reliable

Result Experiment 2: naming ink-colors when conflicting word stimuli were present (NCWd) increased mean time from 63.3s to 110.3s for 100 items (increase of 47.0s, 74%); effect large and highly reliable

Result Experiment 3 (practice effects): eight days of practice on NCWd reduced but did not eliminate the word->color interference, produced a typical learning curve and a 33.9% gain on NCWd, increased group variability on NCWd, and increased interference of color on word reading (RCNd)

Result Experiment 3 (transfer): practice on NCWd produced a smaller improvement on NC (about 13.9% gain), and practice induced a large loss of speed on RCNd (i.e., increased color->word interference); gains and losses were not strongly correlated across individuals

Conclusion: habitual word-reading associations are stronger and more effective than color->name associations (explaining larger word->color interference), differential amounts of prior training account for speed differences between reading and color naming, and targeted practice can modify interference asymmetry and individual variability

Claim about variability and practice: practice on more difficult habitual-opposed tasks (NCWd) increased individual differences, while practice on easier tasks reduced differences, consistent with training amplifying heterogeneity on complex tasks

Claim about sex differences: females named colors faster than males; practice reduced sex differences on color naming, suggesting that the sex difference is at least partly acquired via differential training in color-related verbal activities
